Mo-Bi based catalyst has been synthesized by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method, and tested in selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein (MAL). It is found that the catalysts assisted by PEG exhibited higher selectivity and yield of MAL in oxidation of isobutene. To investigate the role of PEG on Mo-Bi based catalyst, a series of MoBiFeCoCeCs mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method. By combining the characterization of Mo-Bi based catalyst obtained by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, N2 physisorption measurements, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy and scanning electron microscope (SEM), it was verified that the assistance of PEG could change metal composition and states, inhibit agglomeration of particles and adjust acidity of catalyst. Our finding may suggest the relationship of selective oxidation of isobutene with Mo-Bi based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective oxidation PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis Methacrolein Isobutene 1 Introduction Methyl methacrylate (MMA) is an important organic chemical intermediate, which can be used to produce polymethyl methacrylate, surface coating, PVC additives, etc [1]. In recent years, many processes have been developed to produce MMA. Among various production processes, the process using isobutene as raw material has attracted much attention owing to its advantages such as abundant raw materials, high atomic utilization, and clean production process [1,2]. In this process, isobutene can go through four steps to produce MAL: adsorption, formation of intermediates, dehydrogenation, oxidation and desorption [3]. Catalyst is a key factor for the selectivity and yield of MAL and Mo-Bi composite oxide catalysts have been used in industrial MAL production and studied extensively [4–6]. In general, Mo and Bi as main metals provide bismuth molybdate phase. Fe, Ni and Co as metal additives can improve the oxidation-reduction ability of catalysts [7–10], and promote the cycle of Bi0(Mo4+)⇋Bi3+(Mo6+) during the selective oxidation [11]. The addition of alkali metal (K and Cs) can adjust the acidity of catalyst, which affects the adsorption and desorption ability of reactants and products [12]. Therefore, how to develop a better catalyst in the oxidation of isobutene is still an important topic from both fundamental and technological points of view. Unlike the conventional synthesis method, a method of combining surfactant with hydrothermal reaction has received much attention in the field of catalysts preparation, which can control concentration gradient and metal dispersibility easily [13–18]. Cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) [14,15] and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) can assist to synthesize a high specific surface area oxide catalyst due to the hydroxyl protons exchange [13,14]. Polyoxyethylen-polypropylene oxygen-polyoxyethylene (P123) and sodium dodecyl sulfonate (SDS) can form different shapes of micelles and then adsorb metal ions via electrostatic interaction to prepare particles with different morphologies [14,16]. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) has functions of dispersion and stabilization in the preparation of nanoparticles and catalysts [19]. For the aspect of dispersion, the oxygen atom of -CH2-O-CH2- in PEG molecular chains can coordinate with metal ions [20], such as Cu+ [21,22], Zn2+ [21], Fe3+ [23], Co2+ [24], Cs+ [25], Ni2+ [24], etc. Based on this function, catalysts prepared by PEG assistance exhibit high dispersion of active components by scattering metal ions around PEG chains, and then the catalysts acidity is adjustable [21,22]. For the aspect of stabilization, PEG can also prevent particles from aggregation and compression depending on its steric inhibition formed by PEG chains adsorbing and wrapping on the surface of particles [19]. Nanoparticles and catalysts prepared by PEG assistance have finer size and larger specific surface area [17]. Herein, Mo-Bi based catalyst has been prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method and tested in selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein (MAL) with a fixed-bed reactor. All catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physisorption measurements, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and scanning electron microscope (SEM). The role of PEG on Mo-Bi based catalysts has been revealed in isobutene selective oxidation to methacrolein. 2 Experimental Ammonium molybdate(VI) tetrahydrate ((NH4)4Mo7O24•4H2O, 99%), bismuth(III) nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3•5H2O, 99%), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, 98%), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O, 99%), cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3•6H2O, 99.99%), cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3, 99.9%), poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG, MW:200), ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, 25 ∼x223C 28%), nitric acid (HNO3, 65 ∼x223C 68%), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.7%), tert‑butanol (C4H9OH, 99.5%) were purchased from Titan Scientific Corporation (Shanghai, China). Air (79.1% N2 and 20.9% O2) was purchased from Air Products Gas Corporation (Kunshan, China).All reagents were used without purification. 2.1 Catalysts preparation MoBiFeCoCeCs mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis method. Solution A: 0.0081 mol (NH4)4Mo7O24•4H2O and 0.3000 mol PEG-200 were dissolved in 20 mL deionized water at room temperature. Solution B: 0.0071 mol Bi(NO3)3•5H2O, 0.0142 mol Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, 0.0330 mol Co(NO3)2•6H2O, 0.0014 mol Ce(NO3)3•6H2O and 0.0009 Cs2CO3 were dissolved in 27.000 g dilute nitric acid (10 wt%) at 50 °C. Solution B was added into solution A with stirring intensely at 50 °C. Subsequently, dilute ammonia solution (10 wt%) was added to adjust the pH to around 4. Keep stirring for 30 min, the mixture was transferred into the 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160, 180 °C and 200 °C for 24 h. Then, the precipitates were cooled to room temperature and collected by filtering and washing with deionized water and ethanol three times. Finally, the products were dried at 105 °C for 12 h and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h with a ramp of 1 °C/min. The obtained catalysts were named Cat-PEG-x, where x was denoted the hydrothermal temperature (the blank catalyst without PEG was heated at 160 °C, named as Cat-160). The molar ratio of Mo:Bi:Fe:Co:Ce:Cs in feed was 12:1.5:3:7:0.3:0.4. 2.2 Catalysts characterization XRD data was obtained by a MiniFlex600 (Rigaku) X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The angle scan ranges were 10–80 ° with a step increment of 0.02 °. BET surface area analysis of catalysts was obtained by ASAP2020 (Micromeritics) physical adsorption instrument. The samples were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h prior to analysis. FTIR measurements were tested using Thermo Nicolet iS50 spectrophotometer. The samples were analyzed at ambient temperature, at a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the frequency range of 4000–400 cm−1. NH3-TPD tests were performed using the AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics) chemisorption instrument. Prior to analysis, the samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h in Ar atmosphere to remove impurities. After cooled down to room temperature, the samples were kept in a gas mixture of 10% NH3/Ar for 60 min and then heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in Ar atmosphere. XPS analysis was carried out with Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument using monochromatic Al Kα source (hv = 1486.6 eV). The binding energy of XPS data was calibrated of C1 s at 284.6 eV. XRF measurements were performed by XRF-1800 (Shimadzu, Japan) X-ray fluorescence instrument with the scan rates of 80 °/min. SEM images were observed by GEMENI 300 (ZEISS) microscope. 2.3 Catalysts test The catalytic performance for isobutene selective oxidation was evaluated in a continuous flow fix-bed tubular (d= 10 mm) reactor. 4 g catalysts (40–60 mesh) were diluted by quartz sands, loading in the middle of the reactor. Since tert-butanol can be swiftly converted into isobutene completely under 275 °C, tert-butanol was used as raw material. The mixture of tert-butanol and water (molar ratio = 1:1) were gasified in the preheater under 275 °C before entering the reactor with air (90 mL/h). The selective oxidation reaction was conducted under 350 ∼x223C 380 °C at atmosphere pressure and maintained for 24 h at each temperature before products analysis. In addition, the stability test was carried out at 380 °C for 108 h, and samples were taken every 12 h. Light products were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph (Agilent, 7820A) equipped with two sequential columns: Porapak Q for CO2 and other products, and a molecular sieve 13X for O2,N2, and CO gas analysis. The heavy products such as acetone, MAL and acids were quantified by a gas chromatograph (Agilent, 7890B) with HP-INNOWAX capillary column. The conversion of isobutene and selectivity of MAL and CO x were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(3). (1) Isobutene conversion ( % ) = n ( i s o b u t e n e ) i n − n ( i s o b u t e n e ) o u t n ( i s o b u t e n e ) i n × 100 % (2) MAL selectivity ( % ) = n ( M A L ) n ( i s o b u t e n e ) i n − n ( i s o b u t e n e ) o u t × 100 % (3) CO x selectivity ( % ) = n ( C O x ) / 4 n ( i s o b u t e n e ) i n − n ( i s o b u t e n e ) o u t × 100 % Every catalyst was repeated for three times and taken the average to ensure the data reproducibility and accuracy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of catalysts To confirm the elements’ valence state of prepared catalysts, XPS characterization was carried out and the results were summarized in Fig. 1 . Clearly, the catalysts prepared by PEG assistance or under different temperature possess the same valence states of Mo, Bi, Fe and Co elements. In Mo 3d spectra, the peaks at 232.2 and 235.4 eV are ascribed to MoO3 or MoO4 2- (Mo6+) species [26]. The signals corresponding to Bi3+ species are observed at 159.5 and 164.8 eV in the Bi 4f spectra [27]. Additionally, two peaks located at 711.5 and 724.3 eV ascribed to Fe3+ are observed [28], while the peaks appear at 724.3 and 738.0 eV due to the existence of Cs element [29]. The peaks at 780.5 and 796.6 eV are corresponding to Co2+ species in Co 2p spectra [30]. It is obvious that the signal intensity of Fe 2p and Co 2p in Cat-160 catalyst is weaker than the catalysts with PEG assistance. This can be attributed to the low contents of Fe and Co elements on the surface of catalysts without PEG assistance. In brief, Mo, Bi, Fe and Co elements in all the catalysts exist as the valence states of +6, +3, +3 and +2, respectively. XRF and XPS technologies were applied to investigate the elements composition of catalysts and the results were listed in Table 1 . The initial molar ratio of Mo:Bi:Fe:Co:Ce:Cs was 12:1.5:3:7:0.3:0.4 during the synthesis process. From the XRF data, the content of each element in prepared catalysts is lower than the initial content, especially the Co and Cs in Cat-160 catalyst without PEG assistance. Specifically, the contents of Co and Cs in PEG-assisted catalysts increase significantly, which is about 4 times and 2 times of Cat-160 catalyst respectively. Meanwhile, similar results can also be found from XPS data, in which the atomic fraction of Co increases greatly after the assistance of PEG. In the synthetic environment under pH ≈ 4, Co2+ and Cs+ ions are difficult to precipitate, resulting in losing obviously during the filtering process. With PEG assisting, Co2+ and Cs+ ions can coordinate with PEG to form PEG-metal complexes, and then the chains of PEG-metal complexes adsorb and wrap on the precipitated particles easily [18]. This can prevent Co2+ and Cs+ ions from being washing away and inhibit the loss of Co and Cs elements. Eventually, the combustion of residual PEG contributes to the increase of catalysts specific surface area, which is enhanced from 9.4 to 15.2 m2/g. The XRD technique was used to study the effects of PEG on catalysts’ crystalline phase, and the results were pictured in Fig. 2 . The characteristic diffraction peaks of FeMoO4 (JCPDS No. 28–0488) and CoMoO4 (JCPDS No. 21–0868) are located closely due to their similar crystalline structure, so it is difficult to determine whether the peak at 26.5° is corresponding to FeMoO4 or CoMoO4, or a mixture of them. According to the XPS tests of Fe 2p, the valence states of Fe in all catalysts are +3, so the characteristic peak appeared at 26.5 ° is attributed to CoMoO4. In the Cat-160 catalyst, the diffraction peaks at 2θ=24.7°, 28.0°, 29.2° and 31.0° are corresponding to (1 0 2), (0 3 2), (−1 0 4) and (2 1 1) planes of α-Bi2Mo3O12 crystal (JCPDS No. 23–1033), respectively. Fe element exists in Fe2(MoO4)3 crystal, of which the diffraction peaks are located at 2θ=22.7°, 22.8°and 27.5° (JCPDS No. 35–0183). In addition, the intensity of diffraction peaks ascribed to CoMoO4 is weak and the characteristic peaks of MoO3 appear at the same time. Combined with XRF results, it can be found that the CoMoO4 content greatly reduces due to the massive loss of Co2+ ions and extra Mo species are converted to MoO3 after calcination. Whereas, the crystalline phases of the catalysts change obviously with the assistance of PEG in the preparation process. On the one hand, the intensity of peaks ascribed to CoMoO4 becomes stronger and the characteristic peaks of MoO3 disappear after PEG-assisted. The reason is that more molybdenum species form CoMoO4 with Co2+ rather than form MoO3, resulting from the increase of Co content. On the other hand, the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 28.2° attributed to (1 3 1) planes of γ-Bi2MoO6 crystal (JCPDS No. 84–0787) appear and the peaks at 28.0° and 29.2° assigned to α-Bi2Mo3O12 become weaker. It demonstrates that α-Bi2Mo3O12 is partly transformed into γ-Bi2MoO6 with the assistance of PEG. It is worth noting that the peaks of Fe2(MoO4)3 disappear and no characteristic peaks of other Fe-containing compounds are found. It is supposed that the dispersion of Fe3+ ions is improved by coordinating with PEG, which contributes to the size of refined Fe2(MoO4)3 particles below the detection limit of the XRD instrument. In summary, the assistance of PEG can increase the content of CoMoO4, eliminate the existence of MoO3, transform α-Bi2Mo3O12 into γ-Bi2MoO6 and refine Fe2(MoO4)3 particles. To study the structure of catalysts, all catalysts were carried out the FTIR measurements and the characteristic fingerprints in the 700–1100 cm−1 range of the infrared spectrum as shown in Fig. 3 . In the Cat-160 catalyst without PEG assistance, the bands at 950, 932, 901, 847 and 834 cm−1 are attributed to α-Bi2Mo3O12 [31,32] and the bands at 993 cm−1 are ascribed to Mo=O species of hexa-coordinated Mo ions [33,34], which existed in MoO3 species usually. Nevertheless, with the PEG-assisted preparation process, the bands of α-Bi2Mo3O12 weaken gradually and disappear finally with a rise of hydrothermal temperature. The increase of CoMoO4 content results in the appearance of Co-O-Mo bands at 780 cm−1[27]. Moreover, for the catalysts with PEG assistance, the bands at 993 cm−1 assigned to Mo=O species of hexa-coordinated Mo ions disappear and the bands at 938 cm−1 assigned to Mo=O species of tera-coordinated Mo ions appear. All of these results are consistent with the XRD characterization previously, including the phase transition of α-Bi2Mo3O12, the increased content of CoMoO4 and the elimination of MoO3. The tests of NH3-TPD were conducted to confirm the acid properties of catalysts and the results were shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1. It can be observed that all the catalysts exhibit two desorption peaks ascribed to weak acid and strong acid respectively, while the desorption peaks shift towards low temperature for the catalysts assisted by PEG. In addition, the acid quantities of weak acid sites and total acid sites decrease with the assistance of PEG and the rise of hydrothermal temperature. As a result, PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis makes contributions to the weakening of acid strength and the decreases of acid sites quantity. SEM was applied to observe the morphology of catalysts and the images were shown in Fig. 5 . There are different particle morphologies (layered, spherical, massive, etc.) in the catalysts due to the varieties of chemicals and crystalline phases. After PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis, it can be observed that the thickness of the layered particle becomes thinner, and the size of the spherical particles decreases. Overall, the particle size of the Cat-160 catalyst is various and disorderly, while the particles of PEG-assisted catalyst are mostly composed of flake particles, with smaller size and more uniform distribution. As is known, PEG chains are easily absorbed onto the surface of metal oxide colloids [18]. Therefore, PEG can inhibit particles agglomeration and change morphologies due to the steric hindrance [17,21]. 3.2 Performance of catalysts The selective oxidation of isobutene is complicated and has many side reactions [35–38]. Under the conditions in this paper, the main reaction is to form MAL and the by-products are CO x , acetone, butanedione and methallyl alcohol (Fig. 6 ). The catalytic performances of all catalysts were tested, then the yield of MAL and the molar percentage of products were shown in Fig. 7 . It can be found that the MAL yield increases as the reaction temperature increasing and the Cat-160 catalyst has the lowest MAL yield. For the catalyst assisted by PEG, MAL yield increases firstly and then decreases with the rise of hydrothermal temperature, and the optimum temperature is 180 °C. When the reaction temperature is 380 °C, the MAL yield of Cat-160 and Cat-PEG-180 catalysts is 74% and 82%, respectively. Since the excessive oxidation reactions occur and then mass of CO x forms, the MAL selectivity of Cat-160 is low, which is about 77% at 380 °C. But for the catalyst assited by PEG, MAL selectivity is maintained at a high level at all temperatures, which is about 90%. Additionally, the stability test of Cat-PEG-180 catalyst was carried out at 380 °C for 108 h in fixed flow bed reactor while the other conditions remained the same, and samples were taken every 12 h. As seen in Fig. 8 , during the 108 h, the yield of methacrolein and products distribution remain constant, and Cat-PEG-180 catalyst is stable. The reasons for the increase of MAL selectivity after adding PEG include following four aspects: Firstly, excessive oxidation is easy to occur to produce CO x due to the strong oxidation ability of MoO3 [39]. The addition of PEG can inhibit the appearance of MoO3 (from XRD), reduce the production of CO x and then improve the MAL selectivity. Secondly, the addition of PEG can reduce Co loss, and increase the content of CoMoO4 (from XRF and XRD). The CoMoO4 is available for the reduction of Fe2(MoO4)3 and then stabilizes Fe(II) in the form of Fe x Co 1-x MoO4 [40], which can promote the formation of acrolein or methylacrolein [37,41]. Thirdly, the reaction of alkene selective oxidation is directly related to the acid properties of catalysts [42]. Isobutene shows weak basicity due to its two equivalent electron-donating methyl groups. Hence, isobutene is easy to adsorb on the acid center of catalysts during the reaction process, resulting in deep oxidation to generate by-products. Therefore, the catalysts prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis exhibit higher MAL selectivity owing to their weaker acid strength and fewer acid sites (from NH3-TPD). Finally, in the reaction of alkene selective oxidation, Mo=O species can affect the catalysts selectivity [43]. As proposed by Wang et al. [34], isobutene is mainly converted to CO2 on the octahedral MoO6 sites, and MAL on the tetrahedral MoO4 sites. Adding PEG during the preparation process can transform the Mo=O species of hexa-coordinated Mo ions into tetra-coordinated, then reduce the production of CO2 and enhance the MAL selectivity. In comparison with the assessment results listed in Table 2 , the MAL selectivity of Cat-PEG-180 catalyst is obviously superior to the other catalysts. Meanwhile, the isobutene conversion over the Cat-PEG-180 catalyst is also in the top rank. In consequence, the catalysts prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method in this paper possess excellent catalytic performance for the production of MAL from isobutene. 4 Conclusion In this study, in order to further improve catalytic properties and understand the role of PEG, a series of MoBiFeCoCeCs mixed oxide catalysts for isobutene selective oxidation have been prepared by the PEG-assisted hydrothermal synthesis method. The characterization results demonstrated that PEG in the preparation process can not only reduce the Co and Cs loss but also promote the dispersion and structure of active components. The addition of PEG can increase the CoMoO4 content, transfer the crystalline phase of bismuth molybdate, weaken the acid strength, reduce the number of acid sites and transform the coordination number of Mo ions. In the case of oxidation of isobutene, the above changes with the assistance of PEG could remarkably improve the properties of catalytic oxidation. When the reaction temperature is 380 °C, the MAL selectivity and yield are 91% and 82%, respectively. coredata.dc:description: Mo-Bi based catalyst has been synthesized by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method, and tested in selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein (MAL). It is found that the catalysts assisted by PEG exhibited higher selectivity and yield of MAL in oxidation of isobutene. To investigate the role of PEG on Mo-Bi based catalyst, a series of MoBiFeCoCeCs mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by PEG-assisted hydrothermal method. By combining the characterization of Mo-Bi based catalyst obtained by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, N2 physisorption measurements, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy and scanning electron microscope (SEM), it was verified that the assistance of PEG could change metal composition and states, inhibit agglomeration of particles and adjust acidity of catalyst. Our finding may suggest the relationship of selective oxidation of isobutene with Mo-Bi based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the role of PEG on Mo-Bi based catalyst in isobutene selective oxidation to methacrolein
